thread.title: Port Columbus’ new customs facility seen boosting city’s business stature
thread.title_full: Port Columbus’ new customs facility seen boosting city’s business stature

author: Evan Weese
title: Port Columbus’ new customs facility seen boosting city’s business stature
text:
Evan Weese Staff reporter Columbus Business First Evan Weese Staff reporter Columbus Business First Rendering courtesy Lane Aviation Lane Aviation opened a U.S. Customs and Border Protection clearance facility next to its… more Time is money for corporate executives and they could be saving more of it in Columbus. Port Columbus International Airport has opened a new U.S. Customs and Border Protection clearance facility, which officials expect will heighten the city’s stature among business travelers for quickening the process for entering the country. The Lane Aviation building, opened this week, allows passengers on private jets to bypass a customs checkpoint for commercial travelers and save up to several hours, said Mark Myers , a Lane Aviation vice president. Lane Aviation, a Columbus-based fixed-base operator, hopes to increase annual clearances to 400 from 250. Stephen Lyons , executive vice president of the Columbus Partnership, lauded the $900,000, 2,667-square-foot facility. “Streamlining the customs clearance process enhances Columbus’ global reputation as an attractive city in which to conduct business,” Lyons said in a press release. Myers said Tim Hortons Inc. and Scotts Miracle-Gro Co. (NYSE:SMG) are among users of the new facility. The existing U.S. Customs facility inside the Port Columbus terminal will continue serving commercial passengers.
